q: Can you give a step-by step process for taking an image to having the finished plot?
a: I mostly make my images by building generative systems. These systems generate images that can be exported into various formats, such as svg and the plotter-operating script, a process we will cover in detail. Unfortunately the raster-to-vector process is not my expertise, and I highly recommend looking to various plotter community, such as the [DrawingBot discord](https://discord.com/invite/XHP3dBg).

q: How do you avoid or deal with misprints?
a: I don't think it's possible to avoid misprints. My plotting process is filled surprises and it's impossible to be happy with everything. I currently don't do anything to the misprints. I keep them and maybe find ways to use them another way. I've seen some artists cut them up and use them as name cards or postcards.

q: What suggestions do you have for plotting with pencil?
a:
The most challenging part I found with plotting using the pencil is the amount of pressure you need. A common solution is to add weight to the pen. Axidraw provides several ways do so, especially with the brushless servo motor upgrade. Another method I have explored is using sand-textured paper. I've tried sand paper for pastel, which makes colored pencil leaves much more intense marks.
Another challenging point is to adjust the z-axis to compensate the loss of pencil length during the plotting process. I currently don't have a great solution. I recommend checking out the work of [Cory Haber](https://www.coryhaber.com/), who has implemented a mechanism that works for oil sticks.
